I'd like to offer an alternative interpretation for the rationale of starting from 0: offsets. When you have a pointer to some address in memory, and then you have a second pointer that will start from the first pointer and "walk" along the data structure, what do you say the difference is when both pointers are equal,. i.e. when the mobile pointer is pointing to the first element? The difference is zero, that's its offset. So to say you're grabbing the value at address `pointer + 0` (offset zero units from the start of the data) is to say that you're grabbing the first element. if `*(array + 0)` was equivalent to `array[1]` instead of `array[0]`, arrays would be a LOT harder to navigate and off-by-one errors would be a lot more common.  That's the real reason: Pointer arithmetic, file offsets, anywhere you are dealing with offsets (which turns out to be most of the time), zero indexing is more mathematically natural. Or if you're pushing elements into an array by using its length: `array[length] = value`, `memcpy(array + length, array2, MIN(availablesize, length2))`, and then `array` s length is incremented by the number of bytes added. It's simple. People only think it's hard because they deal with C strings which tack on an extra byte at the end while not considering it part of the array (strlen returns the length excluding the final byte).

I’ve always liked that he uses C to teach the basics. Python? No. Python is a very useful language to know. But the cliche about Python programmers not knowing much about computers is true. I’ve helped people learn Python. Even for the intermediate Python programmers, you still need to explain basics like garbage collectors, string, and heap memory. “String?” You may say. Well, yeah, to them it seems like strings are just “a string”. The also don’t know that characters should be easily converted to ints. They don’t know the basics. Now couple that together with the fact that most Python library are pure C, I heavily argue that a newbie starts with C. C++? Perhaps. But I don’t know about giving a new student OOP right away.

C and c++ are both horrible languages, no beginner should dare learn unless they absolutely have to.
@banguard856  why are those bad?

@blindshellvideos  the short answer: is because of the ecosystem.  The reasons why they suck is because in order to make even the most basic programs, they take about 3x as much lines of code, than a more modern language. Generally the more lines of a code the more work you have to do, the more likely you are to make bugs, the harder it is to design, the harder is to change stuff, the harder it is too understand, and the longer it takes to make something.   This is why its mostly just used for operating system development, and embedded development, where performance and precision , matters.  But most modern compilers in other language are built well enough to perform just as well as c and c++ code with less lines of code, so why make it more difficult for yourself? Again more lines of code just means its harder to maintain.   Since most people only like to use c/c++ for operating system development, and embedded basically if you want to do anything outside of that, you are very limited in terms of support. You wont have as many people that know how to code programs outside of that in c++, there wont be as much code or libraries you can reuse for your projects, then there is also a lack of decent tools, meaning you will have to make a-lot of stuff from scratch and your on own if you make errors.   Then portability is always a concern for c/c++ programmers, if you write code on mac, you will have a-lot of work to do to make that same code work on windows. Then with the current amount of stuff that's in c++ library, you could literally be studying the language for 10 years, and still come across code you have never seen before or used in a way you don't know about, Which is horrible if you are trying to maintain a project, who wants to constantly relearn an entire project when you want to make just a simple change?? 🥴   These are just some of the problems. I made the mistake of learning as my first language, because you think of c++ as the first thing you when you hear about programming, and boy I regret it so much every day. Do yourself a favor and learn python, rust, go, or javascript (also a terrible language, but atleast has a good ecosystem). Heck even c# and java is better then c and c++.

I honestly think, C is one of those languages which should be eradicated, buried deep below some pyramids and there should be a penalty for anyone learning it. C is coding terrorism, trying to warp mankind back into the middle ages (okay pre 1955).

@ruffianeo3418  do you know anything about modern programming languages? They are all based to an extent on C. Almost every language has roots in the C language. Eradicating this language would be removing everything: OS, drivers, graphic API, and almost everything that makes up the basics of computer softwares
@ruffianeo3418  You must be fucking joking. In which language is your fancy language intepreter written in ?

​ @banguard856  I get what you mean , but it just preferences what you say. Those languages are not bad you just dont like them and you wish there was something easier.  C may not be the language you start a lot of people say , but talking through my own experience of starting with c# I dont regret it and to be honest I love c# so I am kinda offended when people say C, C# is bad because is not.  its the language used to make programs.   Its like you need flour to make bread. Its like you need cheese in the pizza.  There is nothing bad really ;) You just dont like it, its fine just say "I dont like" not that "Its bad"

​ @banguard856   < this dude is just delusional. If you can code in C, your code will run on pretty much any device. Compatibility is not a huge concern. He is talking about this only because he probably heard one thing from other people or knows only CPP, which can be run under windows platforms. The majority of the functionalities of C are global.  C is perfect for literally anything you want to do if it requires EFFICIENCY. Modern languages are built on c, and they can't be as efficient as c no matter how developers try to improve it.   In terms of the library - anything you want is possible as long as you want to make it. Having to type some extra lines of code is beneficial because if something is more straightforward, it means you are probably losing something. Having everything ready on the side to make things is definitely not a good idea if you are not the author of those libraries since this will not improve your knowledge and will not add any kind of experience to you. If you are a beginner, sure, go ahead use ready-to-use things just for learning purposes, but using libraries just to make things easier, in the cost of losing performance, bloating your program? No, thank you.  Using libraries is not completely stupid, though, even if they are platform-specific. If you know that your program would be vulnerable to some sort of exploit, then go ahead and use the ones with thousands of commits over the years that were kept maintained and used globally and known to be industry standard.   As long as you want to improve yourself while keeping your code as efficient as possible, using pure C with no extra jazz is definitely the path to choose. However, mastering it is not something one can achieve in their lifetime, except for our lord and savior, Terry Andrew Davis.

No. The problem is that a computer is a deterministic machine. That means that it can't produce truly random sequences. It can produce sequences that are too complex for us to predict. These are called "pseudorandom" sequences. They are adequate for most purposes.
But while true is more readable, the performance gain is minimal

@moo I have gotten by extremely well without C or C++, so I disagree that everybody should know it. In fact, for a total newbie it is much better to start with a higher level language than C or C++, which used to be Java, and now it seems to be Python in many schools.

Ronald MacKee “getting by” isn’t good. C is important as a first language because you understand how everything works without any abstractions, you also get a better feel to how memory works when programming and you get a better feel for errors. Python is great, but it doesn’t teach Computer Science at the fundamental level you need to understand what is going on. As you said, you can “get by” With it, this is true for say a physicist, business person, mathematician who do not care about the computer science. But if you plan on becoming a developer or getting into computer science then you must learn C. Also, Python is built using C/C++ so by starting with it you can understand Python at a more deeper level and improve the language yourself and get the feeling of contributing back to the open source community. This guy showed that C isn’t as bad as it’s reputation Perceives it to be. Getting in the C mindset early actually makes programming easier down the road, because you have that lower level knowledge.

@navjotsingh2251  c is a horrible first language and c++, it doesn’t matter if you know the details because a much better higher language will control for you. Forcing a programmer to manage all these Lower level abstractions and write a bunch boiler plate code to do simple stuff will just lead to crappier programs, less work done, and demotivate someone to even learn.
